page.title: 05WANBOROUGH CHURCH AND BARN
page.content:
Wanborough is a small hamlet with a church built in the time of the {Saxons.}It was destroyed by the{Norman invaders but rebuilt by the monks of Waverley Abbey. It was damaged again by the soldiers of{Henry VIII}and there was a secret passage to the nearby manor where two priests holes have been found.
It fell into disuse and was used as a workshop until{1861}when the church was reopened.The old{tythe barn}close to the church was built by the Monks of Waverley Abbey and is one of the finest in the county. It has crown posts and ancient beams but now holds grain drying machinery. The name Wanborough is said to come from a local barrow where bronze age people buried their dead -{"Wenberge".
